issue.title: tool_getparam: repair cleanarg

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
Regression since 9e5669f.

Make sure the "cleaning" of command line arguments are done on the
original argv[] pointers.

Reported-by: Litter White
Fixes #9128

issue.title: tool_getparam: fix cleanarg for wide characters in Windows

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
Follow-up to bf7e887 which fixed cleaning sensitive arguments from the
command line in Windows. That fix (if it works) only works for Windows
multibyte builds (char) and not Windows Unicode builds (wchar_t).

Ref: https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/9128

Closes #xxxx

---

This doesn't work the way I expect. HAVE_WRITABLE_ARGV isn't defined in my Visual Studio Unicode build. If I override that and the sensitive arguments are cleaned, in Process Explorer I can see the command line doesn't change. Is this supposed to work at all on Windows? @MarcelRaad

issue.title: FIxing compilation when HAVE_WRITABLE_ARGV not def

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
Pull request #9399 changed the variable `clearthis` from being a function arg to be a local variable that exists only when the compilation flag `HAVE_WRITABLE_ARGV` is defined.

The not defined case implied that the variable won't exists, but still there were calls to it in other places. This PR puts all mentions of this specific variable under the `HAVE_WRITABLE_ARGV` definition
